article.description:
Arkansas (No. 9 ESPN/USA Today, No. 10 AP) summoned its defense Thursday night when its offense went cold, and left behind
a Southwest Missouri State team that had a brief second-half lead.
article.headline: Lady Razorbacks run away in second half
article.linkText: Arkansas clamps down, runs away from SW Missouri State
article.story:
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Arkansas (No. 9 ESPN/USA Today, No. 10 AP) summoned its defense Thursday night when its offense went cold, and left behind
a Southwest Missouri State team that had a brief second-half lead.

Reserve Dana Cherry scored 13 of her 14 points in the second half as the Lady Razorbacks drew away for a 64-46 victory.

The Lady Bears (3-4) opened the second half by taking a 22-21 lead on a layup by Meg Tierney, who finished with 18 points. Then Arkansas (8-1) started taking care of the ball and forcing turnovers.

``We struggled a little against their zone early, but the difference tonight was our defense,'' Arkansas coach Gary Blair said. ``There will be nights when the offense isn't on, but when we play defense that hard we will always be in good shape.''

After Arkansas opened the game with a 10-0 run, Blair thought
the game would be an easy one.

``But then we started missing the easy transition baskets or
traveling when we had a chance to score easy off of a steal,'' he
said.

A minute into the second half, Shameka Christon made a 15-footer
from the baseline to take back the lead. Then pressure defense and
sharper shooting enabled Arkansas to build its lead to 48-32 with
10:03 to play.

   Christon finished with 13 points, and India Lewis and Ruby Vaden
had 10 each. Cherry, who came in for Sarah Pfeifer with six minutes
left in the first half after Pfeifer broke her nose, pulled down 10
rebounds.

``I think that when you are a starter, you have high
expectations of yourself,'' Cherry said. ``It was good for me to
refocus sitting on the bench and then come off the bench to really
play.''

   In the first half, Arkansas turned over the ball 18 times to 14 for Southwest Missouri. The Lady Razorbacks lost the ball only four times in the second period, while forcing 10 turnovers by the Lady Bears.

Lewis and Lakishia Harper had three steals apiece in the second half. For the game, Arkansas outrebounded the Lady Bears 46-27.

Morgan Hohenberger added 13 points for Southwest Missouri.

Arkansas led 19-6 with 5:25 to play in the first half, but the Lady Bears went on a 14-2 run to close the deficit to 21-20 at the break.

``For our team, it was a good first half,'' Southwest coach Katie Abrahamson-Henderson said. ``We just didn't keep pace in the second half.''
